citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A Jacob's sheep was observed to have an area of missing hair and irritated skin around its horns. When close to the
sheep I noticed a bad odor and the sheep was rubbing the affected areas against the fence. Some blood was see around
the base of the horns. The facility representative said that they have been treating the affected area per a discussion with
the attending veterinarian about 1-2 weeks ago but discussed that consistency in treatment has been difficult (since it is
not a very tame animal) and that the area of skin hasn't improved or might look worse. The signs observed suggest the
area of skin is causing discomfort to the sheep and that the current treatment method is not working. The facility must
communicate with the attending veterinarian if a treatment appears to not be working and needs to have the attending
veterinarian see this animal's condition so that any adjustments in treatment methods can be made based on current
observations.

The perch for the snow macaques had a build-up of soiled waste on it. The facility representative said they have the
employee clean it once a week. A build-up of waste in areas macaques can touch can increase health hazards for the
animals in those areas. To protect their health, areas that nonhuman primates can touch must be spot-cleaned daily to
prevent a build-up of waste. Ensure that a routine of daily spot cleaning non-human primate living areas is maintained in
addition to the regular cleaning and sanitizing schedule.
***Correct by 7/25/2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
A live rat was seen running through the shelter of the non-human primates and an area of excreta between their
enclosures (where the non-human primates don't touch) appeared to be rat droppings. The facility representative said the
pest control method used for other areas can't be employed in this area due to chemical toxicity concerns for the animals.
Animal living areas contaminated by rat droppings increase the risk of disease hazards for the animals living there. To
protect the health of the non-human primates, the facility must maintain a safe and effective program of pest control to
prevent pests from contaminating the shelter.
***Correct by 8/5/2023.

-An area where two panels were joined in a goat pen has panel points over 4 inches long sticking into the pen. Also, a
broken panel point is in an area where the goats could contact it in the same pen. Panel points could cause injury to the
goats. The facility must ensure enclosures are maintained in good repair and protect animals from injury.
-A shelter in the Jacob's sheep enclosure is in disrepair, the cracked roof was sagging low enough the sheep were seen
bumping their horns on it to walk into it and the cracks in the plastic could be areas that sheep could get injured on. The
facility must ensure to maintain shelters in good repair to protect animals from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A Jacob's sheep was observed to have an area of missing hair and irritated skin around its horns. When close to the 
sheep I noticed a bad odor and the sheep was rubbing the affected areas against the fence. Some blood was see around 
the base of the horns. The facility representative said that they have been treating the affected area per a discussion with

not a very tame animal) and that the area of skin hasn't improved or might look worse. The signs observed suggest the 
area of skin is causing discomfort to the sheep and that the current treatment method is not working. The facility must 
communicate with the attending veterinarian if a treatment appears to not be working and needs to have the attending 
veterinarian see this animal's condition so that any adjustments in treatment methods can be made based on current 
observations. 
3.75(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The perch for the snow macaques had a build-up of soiled waste on it. The facility representative said they have the 
employee clean it once a week. A build-up of waste in areas macaques can touch can increase health hazards for the 
animals in those areas. To protect their health, areas that nonhuman primates can touch must be spot-cleaned daily to 
prevent a build-up of waste. Ensure that a routine of daily spot cleaning non-human primate living areas is maintained in 
addition to the regular cleaning and sanitizing schedule. 
***Correct by 7/25/2023 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
A live rat was seen running through the shelter of the non-human primates and an area of excreta between their 
enclosures (where the non-human primates don't touch) appeared to be rat droppings. The facility representative said the 
pest control method used for other areas can't be employed in this area due to chemical toxicity concerns for the animals. 
Animal living areas contaminated by rat droppings increase the risk of disease hazards for the animals living there. To 
protect the health of the non-human primates, the facility must maintain a safe and effective program of pest control to 
prevent pests from contaminating the shelter. 
***Correct by 8/5/2023.

3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
-An area where two panels were joined in a goat pen has panel points over 4 inches long sticking into the pen. Also, a 
broken panel point is in an area where the goats could contact it in the same pen. Panel points could cause injury to the 
goats. The facility must ensure enclosures are maintained in good repair and protect animals from injury. 
 
-A shelter in the Jacob's sheep enclosure is in disrepair, the cracked roof was sagging low enough the sheep were seen 
bumping their horns on it to walk into it and the cracks in the plastic could be areas that sheep could get injured on. The 
facility must ensure to maintain shelters in good repair to protect animals from injury. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
